contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Benjamin Disraeli, 1st Earl of Beaconsfield - Project Gutenberg eText 13619.jpg|thumb|200px|The Earl of Beaconsfield.]] '''Earl of Beaconsfield''', of Hughenden in the County of Buckingham, was a title in the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom]]. It was created in 1876 for [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Disraeli]], a favourite of [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]. Victoria favoured Disraeli's [[Tory]] policies over those of his [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] rival, [[William Ewart Gladstone]]. Disraeli had also promoted the [[Royal Titles Act 1876]] that had given Victoria the title of "[[Emperor of India|Empress of India]]". The subsidiary title of the earldom was '''Viscount Hughenden''', of Hughenden in the County of Buckingham, also in the Peerage of the United Kingdom. In 1868, at the end of his first term as Prime Minister, Disraeli's wife [[Mary Disraeli, 1st Viscountess Beaconsfield|Mary]] had been created '''Viscountess Beaconsfield''', of Beaconsfield in the County of Buckingham, in her own right, allowing her husband to remain a member of the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]]. Lady Beaconsfield died in 1872. When Disraeli became an earl in 1876 he automatically lost his seat in the Commons but remained Prime Minister, leading his government from the [[House of Lords]]. [[Beaconsfield]] is the name of a town in the county of [[Buckinghamshire]]. For most of his parliamentary career, Disraeli served as a [[Buckinghamshire (UK Parliament constituency)|member for Buckinghamshire]]. He owned an estate, [[Hughenden Manor]], in the nearby town of [[High Wycombe]], but never lived in Beaconsfield. His choice of title might have been partly influenced by the fact that in 1794 the conservative political philosopher and parliamentarian [[Edmund Burke]], whom Disraeli admired, had turned down King [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]]'s offer to raise him to the peerage as Lord Beaconsfield.<ref> See, e.g., Isa Carrington Cabell, [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/13220/13220-h/13220-h.htm#BEACONSFIELD "Lord Beaconsfield (1804-1881)"]</ref> In 1878, Disraeli refused Queen Victoria's offer to make him a [[duke]],<ref>See, e.g., [http://www.npg.org.uk/whatson/display/current-displays/benjamin-disraeli1.php Biography] at the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)|National Portrait Gallery]]'s website</ref> accepting instead membership in the [[Order of the Garter]]. The Disraelis died without direct heirs and their titles became extinct; Hughenden Manor passed to Lord Beaconsfield's nephew [[Coningsby Ralph Disraeli]]. == Earls of Beaconsfield (1876) == *[[Benjamin Disraeli|Benjamin Disraeli, 1st Earl of Beaconsfield]] (1804–1881) == Viscountess Beaconsfield (1868) == *[[Mary Anne Disraeli, 1st Viscountess Beaconsfield]] (1792–1872) == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beaconsfield}} [[Category:Earldoms in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Extinct earldoms in the Peerage of the United Kingdom]]
